Chuck Schumer has introduced a bill that would make it a crime to transfer a firearm without a background check. He has styled it the "Fix Gun Checks Act of 2011": 
 
 S. 436 | U.S. Senate Bill | Fix Gun Checks Act of 2011
 
 A quick glance at the proposed legislation reveals the following:
 
 `(a) Definitions- In this section-- 
 `(1) the term `unlicensed transferee' means a person who-- 
 `(A) is not licensed under this chapter; and 
 `(B) desires to received a firearm from an unlicensed transferor; and 
 `(2) the term `unlicensed transferor' means a person who-- 
 `(A) is not licensed under this chapter; and 
 `(B) desires to transfer a firearm to an unlicensed transferee.
 
 The proposed legislation makes it a crime for an "unlicensed transferor" to transfer a firearm to an "unlicensed transferee" without a background check.
 
 All transfers must be done through the assistance of a background check conducted by either a FFL dealer or a local law enforcement agency, unless the state requires a firearm "permit," in which case the "unlicensed transferor" may transfer the firearm if the "unlicensed transferee's" permit is not more than five years old.
 
 Some exceptions to this law appear to be "temporary transfers" (like allowing someone else to hold and shoot your gun at a qualified recognized shooting range-but apparently not for shooting on the family's "back 40." Also allowed for temporary purposes while hunting), transfers for immediate self-defense in life threatening situations, for gifts within the immediate family, and for estate transfers within the family. 
 
 The act would separately require all states to update all prohibited persons into the NCIC database, and it suggests financially punishing states that refuse to comply. Finally, the act would rewrite some definitions on mental health and drug use firearm prohibitions.
 
 The punishment for a violation is linked to 18 U.S.C. 924(A)(5), which sets forth a punishment of imprisonment of up to one year.

 I have to admit that I have a problem with some of the proposals. For example, the one about requiring gun dealers to notify the police if somebody fails a background check. First, the NICS people know when somebody fails...they make the determination. Second, the only reason that you would bother notifying the police is if you think there is some possibility that the person will be charged with trying to illegally obtain a gun. 
 
 The problem I see with this is that for a prohibited person to be charged with trying to purchase the gun, they would have to KNOW they are prohibited, and I think it is a pretty good stretch of the imagination to think that somebody who KNOWS they are prohibited is going to fill out the paperwork to be checked. 
 
 The other problem I see with this is that the majority of NICS failures are either mistakes or end up being unexplained. I have been turned down for firearms purchases twice. Neither time were they able to tell me WHY. The first time the dealer just called back the next day, had then check me again, and it came back approved in less than 3 minutes. The second time I was turned down it was at a gun show, on the last day, so they could not run it again, but I did contact NICS to see WHY I was turned down and they ended up sending me a letter that said they were unable to determine why my purchase was not approved. 
 
 So you are essentially putting extra requirements on gun sellers, and setting up people to be harassed by the police, when the majority of the time the failure to get an approval is not legitimate.
 
 IMO anything that includes more purchase point background checks is a complete and utter waste of time. We have been there, done that, and it is an expensive failure. It is a pain the backside for gun purchasers, owners, and sellers, and it is absolutely worthless when it comes to controlling crime. It has no crime control component AT ALL. 
 
 The same goes for registering firearms. There have been different registration schemes carried out by different cities and states and all of them have been expensive failures. Canada's nationwide registration has pretty much shown us that doing it on a bigger level does not improve the outcome, it just makes it a bigger failure.

 People who do not have eligibility approvals go to prison if they are caught with a gun. For the REST of us, no more stupid background checks, no more dumb restrictions. Just trying to think out loud how this law is supposed to benefit law enforcement if passed....the proposed legislation requires dealers (and LE agencies) who handle the background checks for these secondary sales to complete a form (yet to be devised) similar to the current FFL sale forms that would record the identification of the seller and the purchaser. Unlike initial sales, however, the law requires these secondary sales to be automatically reported to the Attorney General-absent any identification of who the seller or buyer is. Apparently, the record would only be of the date of sale, the FFL dealer/LE agency who made it possible, and would only list the make/model/serial number of the firearm-the identification of the seller and purchaser would be kept by the local dealer/LE agency much like current FFL dealer transaction forms are kept. This would create a national registration of all secondary sales by firearm serial number. Presumably, this would allow LE who recovers a gun (and wants to know who legally had it last) to contact ATF with the serial number, and then ATF could contact the dealer/LE agency which handled the last sale and could provide the information identifying the last seller and purchaser. However, I don't really see how helpful this information would be. Now if you actually found someone in possession of a firearm then it would be relatively easy to determine whether they obtained the firearm without following the background check law's requirements by contacting the AG, giving the serial number, and having the ATF pull the local dealer's or LE agency's transaction form for the last "lawful" sale. This of course allows you to prosecute otherwise peaceful and lawful gun owners who-although they could lawfully have the gun-did not go through the process of proving they could lawfully have the gun before they bought it. But if there is a benefit to society for prosecuting people for having property which the law says they can legally possess merely because they did not fill out some paperwork then I don't see it. The law certainly does not seemed aimed at helping prosecute those found in possession who are already disqualified (felons, etc.)-we don't need this new law to help do that.
 
 So it looks to me like the main thrust of the legislation is aimed at the seller. It looks like an attempt to modify the felony criminal liability for selling to someone he knew or should have known was disqualified from having a gun by including a much broader misdemeanor crime to sell to someone, even someone who could legally buy the gun, without a background check. 
 
 However, the legislation still makes it illegal to possess a firearm that you acquired without having undergone a background check. Every traffic stop or other law enforcement/citizen encounter in which law enforcement learns that the citizen possesses a firearm would now allow for suspicion that the firearm may have been obtained without going through the background check process. The only way to easily and readily dispel this suspicion of not having illegally obtained a firearm would be by a universal requirement on the part of the gun owner to carry some sort of documentation stating how you came to possess the firearm without violating the background check law. I see no excuse for a misleading question caused by lack of knowledge, and I see no justification for an attempt to intentionally mislead those being questioned. While we are on the subject of "loopholes," The "gun show" question seems to suggest a majority favor "require sellers at gun shows to run background checks." Did the survey team tell the Virginians they surveyed that all dealer sales at gun shows require background checks, or were they willing to allow those who did not know better to answer the question under the possible mistaken belief that gun shows were completely unregulated? Did they also conceal from those surveyed that the Attorney General already has the power to order FFL dealers to report "bulk" (or even single) sales of "assault weapons"? 
 
 Here is another question I have: Assume for a moment that the survey team calls me and asks my opinion of whether we should "do more to keep guns out the hands of bad people," and assume I responded "I don't know what the current laws are could you explain them to me before I answer the question." Based upon the misleading nature of the questions I have already seen asked, do you think I would have gotten either a knowing or honest answer from the survey team to ensure I gave them an informed opinion in response? 
 
 Looking again at the Mayors' site you linked, I find it technically correct but intellectually dishonest to claim support by a "plurality" of people in VA and AZ whom they say "feel" their states have done "too little" since the Tucson/Va Tech shootings. Assuming (without much confidence) that their questions generated informed responses, their data for VA shows 38 percent say too little, 38 percent say too much/right amount and 24 percent say they don't know. Their Arizona data shows 42 percent say too little, 45 percent say too much/right amount, and 13 percent say don't know. A more honest analysis of this data is an even split of those surveyed in VA between needing/not needing more legislation, and a slim majority in AZ who say there is either too much or the right amount gun control legislation already-all from a survey method that is concealing from those surveyed the reality of how current gun regulations really work. 
 
 And this is a major credibility issue for me. Consider this example: Assume I conducted a poll here and asked everyone to tell me whether in their opinion the juries in trials I prosecuted over the last year gave out too much/the right amount/or not enough time for the crimes people were found guilty of. Would the opinion poll be worth anything if those answering had no idea what the crimes or the sentences were? The poll would be worthless. And so in looking at the poll conducted for the Mayors, how can I accept the validity of an opinion poll that asks me to assume it is the result of informed opinion when the questions themselves conceal the true nature of the facts the opinions should be based upon?
